section.name: 3. Quick Start
section.p:
This section shows how to write a simple command-line application using Cayenne. For a more detailed discussion read "Writing Cayenne Applications" section. This tutorial follows these steps:
Create Tutorial Directory Structure.
Prepare Tutorial Database.
Create Cayenne Configuration Files.
Generate Java Code for DataObjects.
Write Application Code.
Compile and Run the Application.

subsection.name: 3.1 Create Tutorial Directory Structure
subsection.p: - Copy cayenne.jar file that is a part of Cayenne distribution to the JRE extensions directory (normally a directory like $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/ext) or make it otherwise accessible in the CLASSPATH of the application.
- Create tutorial project directory (further referred to as "project directory") anywhere on the filesystem. For example:

subsection.name: 3.2 Prepare Tutorial Database
subsection.p: To run this tutorial user must have access to a relational database with privileges sufficient to perform tables creation, select, insert and update queries. Run the following script to create test tables (script is tested on MySQL, but it should be easy to port to any other RDBMS): tutorial1.sql.

subsection.name: 3.3 Create Cayenne Configuration Files
subsection.p:
Use CayenneModler tool to create Cayenne configuration files including "cayenne.xml", data map file and data source file. Sample files used for this tutorial can be downloaded from here:
cayenne.xml
datamap.xml
driverinfo.xml
These XML files should be copied to the project directory. DataSource connection info should be changed to reflect the information specific to the user database. This can be done either manually or by using CayenneModeler (recommended).

subsection.name: 3.4 Generate Java Code for DataObjects
subsection.p:
Use CayenneModeler to generate Java classes for DataObjects. Sample generated files that can be used with this tutorial can be found here:
_Artist.java
Artist.java
_Painting.java
Painting.java
_Gallery.java
Gallery.java
Create a subdirectory called "test" under the project directory. Save the source code under this new directory.

subsection.name: 3.5 Write Application Code
subsection.p: Create a simple application that uses Cayenne. Here is a sample Java class source code: Main.java. Download it and save under "test" directory in project directory.
